metadata.title: Chemical bonding boosts nano-rose-like MoS2 anchored on reduced graphene oxide for superior potassium-ion storage

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Nano Energy
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/nanoen
Full paper
Chemical bonding boosts nano-rose-like MoS2 anchored on reduced graphene oxide for superior potassium-ion storage
Shaokun Chonga,b, Lan Suna, Chengyong Shud, Shengwu Guoa, Yongning Liua,*, Wei (Alex) Wangb,**, Hua Kun Liuc,***
a State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, School of Material Science and Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, 710049, PR China b John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences, Harvard University, Cambridge, MA, 02138, United States c Institute for Superconducting and Electronic Materials, University of Wollongong, Wollongong, NSW, 2522, Australia d School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, 710049, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Potassium-ion battery Anode material Chemical bonding Molybdenum disulfide
A B S T R A C T
The abundant and low-cost potassium resources promote potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) as promising energy storage devices, thus accelerating the investigation of ideal electrode materials to accommodate the large-size Kions. Here, a nano-rose-like MoS2 confined in reduced graphene oxide (MoS2@rGO) is evaluated as anode material to boost K-ion storage. The MoS2@rGO hybrid not only features large specific surface area for excellent electron conductivity and facile K-ions diffusion, but also provides a robust three-dimension (3D) network with stable interfacial connection through strong chemical bonds (Mo-C and Mo-O-C) between MoS2 and rGO, which can alleviate the mechanical stress to guarantee the structure stability during cycling. It is also confirmed that both intercalation and conversion reaction mechanisms, based on four-electrons-transfer, play an important role in K-ions insertion/extraction. Hence, the initial capacity of 438.5 mAh·g−1 with excellent cycling stability (capacity retention of 95.0% after 200 cycles) at 100mA g−1 and the remarkable rate capability (196.8 mAh·g−1 at 2 A g−1) among many reported anodes are achieved for MoS2@rGO. No obvious fading at 500mA g−1 can be observed over ultra-long lifespan of 1000 cycles. Finally, the K-ion full cells are assembled with K2Fe[Fe(CN)6] cathode to demonstrate the practical application.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Natural energy exhaustion and environmental pollution have become the major problems threatening human development, thus exploring advanced electrical energy storage (EES) technologies to integrate the renewable energy (such as solar and wind powers) into the smart electric grids is extremely urgent [1,2]. Nowadays lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), one of the dominant EES devices, have achieved significant progress in the field of portable electronic devices (PEDs) and electric vehicles (EVs) owing to their high energy density and long-term cycling life [3–5]. However, LIBs cannot satisfy the ever-increasing need for PEDs, EVs and large-scale stationary applications in the future because of the rising cost and limited storage of lithium resources in the earth's crust, further promoting the investigation on new types of rechargeable batteries on the basis of high reserves and low cost. Therefore, many alkali-ion batteries with the same “rocking chair”
operating principles as LIBs, such as sodium-ion batteries (NIBs) and potassium-ion batteries (KIBs), have been extensively studied [6–8]. The reversible K-ions storage in the graphite anode already developed for LIBs has been confirmed, which is a significant advantage for KIBs over NIBs [9]. Moreover the much lower redox potential of −2.93 V for K/K+ than −2.71 V for Na/Na+ (vs. the standard hydrogen electrode), suggests that KIBs can deliver higher operating voltage and energy density compared to NIBs [10]. In addition, the higher transport number and mobility of K-ions than Li and Na-ions in the non-aqueous electrolyte induced by the weaker Lewis acidity can also be acquired for KIBs, delivering outstanding rate property [7,11]. Hence, developing suitable electrode materials to realize the reversible intercalation/ deintercalation of K-ions with the larger ionic radius of 1.38 Å compared to Li-ion (0.76 Å) and Na-ion (1.02 Å) will accelerate the application of KIBs as valuable EES system.
Up to now, numerous kinds of materials were verified as cathodes to
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.nanoen.2019.103868 Received 11 May 2019; Received in revised form 21 June 2019; Accepted 1 July 2019
* Corresponding author. ** Corresponding author. *** Corresponding author. E-mail addresses: ynliu@mail.xjtu.edu.cn (Y. Liu), wwang3@g.harvard.edu (W.A. Wang), hua@uow.edu.au (H.K. Liu).
Nano Energy 63 (2019) 103868
Available online 02 July 2019 2211-2855/ © 2019 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
T
accommodate K-ions, including polyanionic compounds [12,13], transition metal (TM) oxides [14,15], organic compounds [16,17] and Prussian blue analogues [2,18], exhibiting reversible K-ions storage process and revealing the detailed electrochemical mechanisms. Meanwhile, graphite, soft and hard carbon, organics based on intercalation behavior were successfully employed as anode materials for KIBs, which present good cycling stability [9,19–22]. However, the low capacity below 300 mAh·g−1 becomes the main challenge for K-ion full cell with high energy density. Recently, the anode electrodes with alloy reaction process exhibit improved specific capacity with low operating voltage, while the large volume expansion induces poor cycling lifetime [23–27]. In addition, TM oxides, carbides, phosphides, selenides, fluoride and nitride were also widely studied as anodes for KIBs, which promoted the development of conversion mechanism materials and achieved great process for K-ions storage [28–37].
TM dichalcogenides, a type of two dimension (2D) materials, have gained considerable attention as anodes for alkali-ions storage owing to their graphene-like lamellar structure and narrow-band gap feature [38]. In particular, MoS2 possesses unique sandwich-like structure formed by weak Van der Waals force between adjacent layers and strong covalent bond linked Mo and S atoms, which provides substantial redox sites with four-electron-transfer and developed 2D channels with large interlayer distance [39], thus promoting it as an ideal host for fast K-ions insertion/extraction. However, the huge volume change during charge/discharge process also exists for MoS2, resulting in severe capacity decay for long-term cycles [39,40]. In order to solve this key issue, a common strategy is strongly coupling MoS2 with conductive carbonaceous skeleton materials to form flexible carbon matrix, which can boost electrochemical kinetics and sustain the integrity of electrode via buffering the volume variation.
Herein, we design a nano-rose-like MoS2 anchored on reduced graphene oxide (denoted as MoS2@rGO) by chemical bonds of Mo-C and Mo-O-C as anode for KIBs. The unique conductive matrix with high specific surface area endows robust endurance for protecting the structural integrity from large volume expansion and superior electrochemical kinetics for fast electrons and K-ions transport. Therefore, MoS2@rGO hybrid delivers much higher initial capacity of 438.5 mAh·g−1, more superior cycling stability with the retention of 95.0 % after 200 cycles at 100mA g−1 and preeminent rate capability (196.8 mAh·g−1 at 2000mA g−1) than pristine MoS2 and MoS2@CNT. Beside, ultra-long cycling lifetime over 1000 cycles with the capacity retention of 424.6 mAh·g−1 (116.9%) can also be achieved. The ex situ Raman and XRD results verify that MoS2@rGO undergoes the combination mechanisms of intercalation and conversion reactions. We also successfully assemble the full cell using K2Fe[Fe(CN)6] cathode, presenting high initial capacity of 124.9 mAh·g−1 and satisfactory cyclability over 10 cycles (119.1 mAh·g−1) at 20mA g−1.

sections.heading: 2.1. Material preparation
sections.text: CNT was purchased from Sigma and GO was prepared via Hummers’ method. MoS2@rGO was synthesized through a facile one-step hydrothermal strategy. 2 mmol NaMoO4·2H2O and 10mmol thiourea were fully dissolved into 70mL deionized water, and GO was further dispersed in the above uniform solution under sonication for 1 h. The weight percent of GO in the composite is 15%. Afterward, the solution was transferred to 100mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave, which was heated at 210 °C for 24 h. The MoS2@rGO powder was obtained after centrifugation, washing with deionized water and ethanol as well as freeze drying. The bare MoS2 and MoS2@CNT hybrids were fabricated by the above approach without GO and using CNT instead of GO, respectively.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material characterization
sections.text: Field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM, JSM-6390) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEOL JEM-2100CX) were carried out to observe morphology and analyze micro-structure of samples, and the energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS) was employed to collect the elemental mapping images. The crystal structure was identified by X-ray diffraction (XRD, UltimaIV-185, Rigaku) at 40 kV and 40mA using Cu Ka radiation, whose patterns were refined using Rietveld method based on program GSAS. Raman was tested on HR 800, JY Labram spectrometer, and the N2 adsorption-desorption measurement was performed on Micromeritics ASAP 2460 analyzer to acquire Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area and pore structure information. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Axis Ultrabld, Kratos) was operated using a monochromatic Al K alpha radiation. Thermogravimetry (TG) analysis was conducted on TGA/ DSC3+instrument (Mettle Toledo) from room temperature to 700 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C·min−1 in air.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical measurements
sections.text: The electrochemical performances of anode materials were tested by CR2025-type coin half-cells, which were assembled in an Ar-filled glove box (Super 1220/750, Mikrouna) with metallic K-sheet as counter electrode and glass fiber as separator. The electrolyte was 1M KPF6 dissolved in the mixture of ethylene carbonate, diethyl carbonate and propylene carbonate (1:1:1 by volume). The uniform slurry was prepared by mixing the active material, acetylene black and polyvinylidene fluoride binder at the weight ratio of 8:1:1 in N-methyl pyrrolidinone, which was coated onto a Cu foil and dried at 60 °C overnight under vacuum. The working electrodes were further fabricated by pressing for densification and cutting into disks with the size of Փ12 mm, whose mass loading of the active material was around 1.0 mg. The full cell was assembled using K2Fe[Fe(CN)6] as cathode electrode, which was prepared through spreading the slurry onto an Al foil with the same procedure as above. It is worth mentioning that the MoS2@ rGO anode needs to be fully discharged to 0.01 V for pre-insertion potassium before the assembly of full cell, and the mass ratio of cathode/ anode was controlled about 1:1. Galvanostatic charge/discharge measurements were performed at different current densities on a battery tester (Neware, China) at 25 °C in the potential range of 0.01–3.0 V for anode, 2.0–4.5 V for cathode and 1.0–4.1 V for full cell. Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was measured at different scan rates and electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded within a frequency range from 100mHz to 100 kHz using an amplitude of 5mV, which were tested on a Solartron electrochemical potentiostat (1470E). The electrodes were acquired by disassembling the cells at various cutoff voltages during the initial charge/discharge and after several cycles. After rinsing with dimethyl carbonate several times and drying at room temperature in the glove box, the morphology and structure for samples were further analyzed by ex situ XRD and SEM.

sections.heading: 3.1. Morphology and structure analyses
sections.text:
The fabrication strategy of hierarchical MoS2@rGO nanostructured material is schematically illustrated in Fig. 1a. Bare MoS2 micro-spheres assembled by ultrathin nano-sheets can be observed from FESEM images in Fig. 1b and c, which were synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method using Na2MoO4 as Mo source and CH4N2S as S source. For MoS2@rGO, there is formation of Mo-C and Mo-O-C chemical bonds between the rGO and Mo ions when S-ions released from the thiourea react with Mo. Thus MoS2 nanosheets gradually assemble to nano-roses with the size of 200–500 nm along with being wrapped uniformly by rGO via chemical bonds as shown in Fig. 1f and g, which is beneficial
for fast K-ions diffusion and electrons transport as well as superior structure stability. By comparison, MoS2@CNT composite can also be prepared through the same procedure as MoS2@rGO using CNT instead of GO, in which CNT can homogeneously intertwine with MoS2 nanoroses via Mo-C bond in Fig. 1d and e.
The morphology characteristics and detailed microstructures are further studied by TEM as presented in Fig. 2. It can be seen clearly from the TEM image (Fig. 2a) that pristine MoS2 dispalys typical speherical morphology composed of numerous thin nanosheets (Fig. 2b), and the EDS elemental mapping result confirms the presence and uniform distribution of Mo and S elements in Fig. 2c. The high-resolution (HR) TEM image in Fig. 2d exhibits obvious lattice fringes stacking multiply layers with interplanar spacing of 6.37 Å, corresponding to (002) plane of hexagonal MoS2 phase. The ultrathin nanosheets (Fig. 2f) are anchored on rGO to form nano-rose-like MoS2@rGO hierarchical hybrid as displayed in Fig. 2e. Few stacked-layered nanosheets can be seen for MoS2@rGO in Fig. 2g, where the lattice distance can be measured to 6.38 Å, which is ascribed to (002) plane of hexagonal structure. Fig. 2h exhibits the EDS mapping images, signifying that Mo, S and C elements are uniformly distributed throughout the MoS2@rGO nanorose and proving that MoS2 is tightly surrounded by rGO.
The Rietveld refinement XRD patterns of bare MoS2, MoS2@CNT and MoS2@rGO are exhibited in Fig. 3a, Fig. S1 and Fig. 3b, respectively, which can be well indexed to 2H-MoS2 hexagonal phase with the space group of P63/mmc [38,41], and the detailed refinement results are listed in Table S1, S2 and S3. Fig. S2 displays the pristine XRD patterns of the above three samples, where the weak and broad peaks located at around 23.7° appear for MoS2@CNT and MoS2@rGO,
corrsponding to (002) plane of hexagonal graphite structure. Besides, the (002) planes of 2H-MoS2 phase for the three materials shift to much lower positions (about 13.89°) compared to the standard PDF card (14.40°, JCPDS 37–1492) [41], indicating an increased interlayer spacing from 6.15 Å to 6.37 Å, which is consistent with the HRTEM results. Raman spectra of samples are further employed to study the structure features as displayed in Fig. 3c. The bands of 377–340 cm−1 and 405- 406 cm−1, respectively assigned to in-plane E12g and out-of-plane A1g vibrational modes of MoS2 [41,42], can be observed for three materials. The frequency separation between E12g and A1g modes is 26.40 cm−1 for MoS2@rGO, which is much lower than that of bare MoS2 (28.13 cm−1) and MoS2@CNT (28.12 cm−1), manifesting the few-layered MoS2 nanosheets [43,44]. The decreased MoS2 layer numbers and the enhanced interlayer spacing can facilitate the K-ions intercalation/deintercalation and deliver short ion diffusion paths. Other two peaks for MoS2@CNT and MoS2@rGO located at 1336 and 1595 cm−1 are indexed to the sp3hybridized amorphous carbon (D-band) and sp2-hybridized graphitic carbon (G-band), respectively, confirming the presence of carbon for both samples, which can improve the electron conductivity [41,44].
Fig. S3a presents the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of samples, displaying typical type-IV profiles with H4 hysteresis loops, which demonstrates the existence of mesoporous structure. Apart from more developed mesoporous and macropore features for MoS2@CNT and MoS2@rGO from Fig. S3b compared to pristine MoS2, another peaks with the pore size distribution of about 2.6 nm derived from CNT and rGO appear according to the Barrett-Joyner-Halenda model. Furthermore, MoS2@rGO exhibits a BET specific surface area of 22.6 m2 g−1, which is much higher than that of MoS2 (7.0 m2 g−1) and MoS2@CNT
(12.1 m2 g−1). Hence, hierarchical MoS2@rGO nano-roses with high specific surface area and extensive pore structure will be beneficial to the K-ions transport and act as a buffer for the volume expansion during K-ions insertion/extraction.
XPS was tested to study the composition, valence states of ions and chemical bonding information. As shown in Fig. S4, the survey spectra verify that MoS2@CNT and MoS2@rGO are composed of Mo, S, O and C elements. In the high resolution S 2p spectra in Fig. S5, the peaks at approximately 163.4 eV and 162.3 eV for all samples are attributed to S 2p1/2 and S 2p3/2 of S2− [39,45], respectively. Fig. 3d presents the Mo 3d spectra, in which two main peaks with the binding energies of 232.8 eV for Mo 3d3/2 and 229.5 eV for Mo 3d5/2 are assigned to Mo4+ in MoS2, and the weak peak at 236.2 eV corresponding to Mo6+ indicates the formation of MoO3 on the surface of MoS2 [39,45]. It is worth mentioning that there are a pair of peaks located at 232.0/ 228.9 eV for MoS2@CNT and MoS2@rGO except MoS2, which are ascribed to Mo-C bond [43], uncovering the strong covalent bond interaction between MoS2 and carbon from CNT or rGO. The C 1s spectrum of MoS2@CNT in Fig. 3e can be fitted into two peaks of 284.8 eV for CC/C=C and 285.7 eV for C-O. Four deconvoluted peaks at about 284.8, 285.6, 286.5 and 288.6 eV, indexed to C-C/C=C, C-O, C-O-Mo and C=O [40], respectively, can be observed from C 1s spectrum of MoS2@ rGO in Fig. 3f, indicating that MoS2 is linked with rGO by bonding Mo and oxygen atoms from functional groups on rGO.

sections.heading: 3.2. Electrochemical performances
sections.text:
The K-ions storage performances were evaluated between 0.01 and 3.0 V (vs. K/K+) as presented in Fig. 4. The first five charge-discharge curves of MoS2@rGO at 100mA g−1 are shown in Fig. 4a, where two voltage plateaus can be observed during the initial discharge process and there is a corresponding charge plateau centered at about 1.7 V.
The slopy discharge curves overlap in the subsequent cycles, and the charge plateaus still remain unchanged, suggesting highly reversible electrochemical process. Fig. S6 gives the CV profiles of MoS2@rGO, presenting two obvious cathodic peaks at 1.69 V and 0.62 V during the initial discharge process, which are respectively related to K-ions intercalation into MoS2 layers to form K0.4MoS2 compound and the conversion reaction to generate Mo and K2S [39]. Two strong anodic peak at 1.74 V and 2.56 V, ascribed to the reversible oxidation process, appear during the first K-ions extraction process. During the second cathodic process, much more obvious reduction peaks can be observed for MoS2@rGO compared with bare MoS2 (Fig. S7a) and MoS2@CNT (Fig. S8a), signifying enhanced kinetics of K-ions. MoS2@rGO delivers the initial discharge/charge capacities of 607.4/438.5 mAh·g−1 at 100mA·g−1, which are much higher than those of bare MoS2 (530.9/ 356.1 mAh·g−1) in Fig. S7b and MoS2@CNT (537.2/390.7 mAh·g−1) in Fig. S8b. According to the TG result (Fig. S9), the percentage of rGO in the composite can be determined to be about 15.5%, which is in accordance with the experiment part. As shown in Fig. S10, pristine rGO displays the first reversible charge capacity of 268.2 mAh·g−1. Hence, about 41.6 mAh·g−1 of the total capacity was contributed by rGO, which is far less than that contributed by MoS2. The best cycling stability with the charge capacity retention of 416.7 mAh·g−1 (95.0%) after 200 cycles is acquired for MoS2@rGO in Fig. 4b, while pristine MoS2 and MoS2@CNT suffer serious capacity deccay with the retention values of 39.9 mAh·g−1 (11.2%) and 120.4 mAh·g−1 (30.8%).
Fig. 4c exhibits the rate properties of all samples from 100 to 2000mA g−1, where the highly reversible capacities of 364.8, 302.9, 253.0 and 196.8 mAh·g−1 can be obtained for MoS2@rGO at the current densities of 200, 500, 1000 and 2000mA g−1, displaying excellent rate capability. Nevertheless, the capacities of MoS2 and MoS2@CNT decrease drastically from 247.1 to 346.7 to 22.2 and 39.7 mAh·g−1, respectivly. The comparison of rate performances for the most recent
reported TM compouds, organics and carbon-based materials with our work is shown in Fig. 4d and e [31,32,35,36,39,46–57]. It can be seen obviously that hierarchical MoS2@rGO nano-roses present the highest capacities between 100 and 2000mA g−1. The ultra-long cycling lifetime, measured at high current density of 500mA g−1, further highlight the most appealing property of MoS2@rGO composite. As presented in Fig. 4f, MoS2@rGO shows the highest initial charge capacity of 363.2 mAh·g−1 and the most outstanding cyclability, maintaining the reversible capacity of 424.6 mAh·g−1 (116.9%) over 1000 cycles, while much lower capacities of 82.8 mAh·g−1 (30.8%) and 231.2 mAh·g−1
(69.5%) are retained for MoS2 and MoS2@CNT, respectively. The increase of capacity is attributable to the ultra-thin graphene sheets, which can efficiently move MoS2 sheets toward higher level of ordering upon cycling to form more active-sites for K-ions storage [58,59]. After the initial several cycles, the Coulombic efficiencies for MoS2@rGO are approximately 98% both at 100 and 500mA g−1, manifesting great
electrochemical reversibility and highly stable SEI film. As far as we know, MoS2@rGO displays the highest initial capacity and the most great cycling stability compared with ever reported MoS2-based anodes for KIBs as shown in Table S4 [38,39,50,60].

sections.heading: 3.3. Electrochemical mechanism
sections.text:
Cyclic voltammetry tests were conducted at various sweep rates to further assess the solid state diffusion kinetics behavior of K-ions as well as analyze the contributions of diffusion controlled and capacitive capacities. As displayed in Fig. 5a, the analogue shapes with small peak shifts as increasing the scanning rates can be preserved from the CV curves of MoS2@rGO, revealing fast response ability. According to the literature, Randles-Sevcik equation of Ip=2.69×105 n3/2 A D1/2 C v1/2 describes the relationship between peak current Ip and scanning rate v (n, A, D and C are number of electrons, surface area of electrode,
diffusion coefficient and concentration of K-ions, respectively) [33,61]. The equation can be further simplified as Ip= a D1/2 v1/2 (a stands for the constant), where the slopes of the fitting linear relationship between Ip and v1/2 represent the value of a D1/2 to evaluate the diffusion coefficient of K-ions. It can be obviously observed from the fitting results in Fig. 5b that MoS2@rGO shows much faster K-ions diffusion capability than MoS2 and MoS2@CNT, whose CV curves are respectively presented in Figs. S11 and S12. Additionally, the current response (i) at a fixed potential is related to the scan rate (v) based on the equation of i= k1 v + k2 v1/2, in which k1 v and k2 v1/2 correspond to the current contributions from surface capacitance and K-ions diffusion [51], respectively. Furthermore, the values of k1 and k2 can be obtained via the fitting linear relationship between i/v1/2 and v1/2 according to the equation of i/v1/2= k1 v1/2 + k2 [51]. It can be calculated that the total charge consists capacitive effect of 21.4% and K-ions insertion behavior of 78.6% at 0.1mV s−1 for MoS2@rGO in Fig. 5c. Fig. 5d summarizes the exact contribution values at various scanning rates, where diffusion effect delivers 83.8%, 78.6%, 72.2%, 67.9%, 62.2% and 53.8% of the K-ions storage from 0.05 to 1.0mV s−1, indicating that K-ions diffusion process plays a dominant role in the total capacity.
EIS results in Fig. S13 indicate that MoS2@rGO displays much lower charge-transfer resistance (Rct) values before cycling and after 100 cycles than MoS2 and MoS2@CNT, demonstrating remarkable electrochemical kinetics. It can be seen visibly from the ex situ SEM images
that the nano-rose shape for MoS2@rGO can be well maintained after 100 cycles in Fig. S14, while bare MoS2 undergoes drastic degradation to form nano-fragments (Fig. S15) induced by huge volume expansion during cycling, which manifests superior structure stability for MoS2@ rGO. Therefore, the high capacity, excellent cycling stability and exceptional rate capability for MoS2@rGO are attributed to the novel 3D hierarchical architecture, in which the conductive network with high specific surface area and developed porous structure can facilitate outstanding kinetics for fast electrons transport and K-ions diffusion, and the matrix with strong chemical bonds also works as robust buffer to endure the volume change during charge/discharge process, thus preserving the morphology stability.
To gain more insight into the electrochemical reaction mechanism of MoS2@rGO composite, the ex situ Raman and XRD were conducted at various depths denoted in the first charge-discharge profile at 100mA g−1 in Fig. 5e. The ex situ Raman spectra are shown in Fig. 5f, the peaks of in-plane (E12g) and out-of-plane (A1g) phonon modes gradually shift to much lower positions till discharging to 1.05 V (iii position), demonstrating that the K-ions have inserted into MoS2 to form KxMoS2 via an intercalation process along with the increase of interplanar spacing. Further both peaks disappear when discharging to 0.01 V (v position), indicating the occurrence of the conversion reaction. During the charge process, the conversion and deintercalation reactions proceed reversibly, and both modes can be recovered at the
fully charged state (viii), uncovering excellent electrochemical reversibility. Fig. 5g reveals the ex situ XRD patterns, where the peaks of MoS2 completely disappear and several peaks related to K2S occur at the state of v. The pattern charging to 3.0 V maintains the peaks of MoS2, which is consistent with the result of ex situ Raman, proving highly reversible K-ions storage process. On the basis of ex situ measurement results, the electrochemical mechanism can be described as follows: MoS2 + xK+ + xe− ↔ KxMoS2, KxMoS2 + (4 - x)K+ + (4-x) e− ↔ Mo + 2K2S [40].

sections.heading: 3.4. K-ion full cell
sections.text:
K-ion full cell was assembled to evaluate the practical application of MoS2@rGO with K2Fe[Fe(CN)6] cathode electrode, and the diagrammatic view is displayed in Fig. 6a. The anode should be pre-discharged to 0.01 V with K metal sheet to remove the first large irreversible capacity and supplement enough K amount. The cycling stability is evaluated at 20mA g−1 as presented in Fig. 6b, where a high first discharge capacity of 124.9 mAh·g−1 can be achieved, maintaining the capacity of 119.1 mAh·g−1 (95.4%) after 10 cycles. The corresponding initial five charge/discharge curves are exhibited in Fig. 6c, presenting obvious two sets of plateaus during K-ions intercalation/deintercalation process, which is in keeping with the half cell for K2Fe[Fe(CN)6] cathode in Fig. S16. Fig. 6d gives the cycling profile of the full cell at 50 mA g−1, delivering an initial discharge capacity of 68.2 mAh·g−1
and extremely stable cycling performance with the capacity retention of 50.0 mAh·g−1 after 50 cycles.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, we proposed a nano-rose-like MoS2@rGO hybrid architecture, synthesized through one-step hydrothermal approach, as anode material for enhancing K-ions storage performance. The MoS2 is
wrapped uniformly by rGO to form robust interface joint between MoS2 and rGO via strong chemical bonds of Mo-C and Mo-O-C, which provides large specific surface area and developed 3D network buffer zone. These desirable features are integrated into the MoS2@rGO hierarchical hybrid with fast electrochemical kinetics, high reversibility and great structural stability to buffer the huge volume expansion during charge/ discharge process. As a result, the best electrochemical performances for MoS2@rGO compared with bare MoS2 and MoS2@CNT, including high first capacity of 438.5 mAh·g−1, outstanding cyclability with the capacity retention of 416.7 mAh·g−1 (95.0%) over 200 cycles at 100mA g−1 and the most preeminent rate performance at various current densities among many published electrodes, have been achieved. Furthermore, MoS2@rGO also displays ultra-long cycling life over 1000 cycles at 500mA g−1, maintaining the capacity of 424.6 mAh·g−1 (116.9%). Electrochemical mechanism analysis reveals that Kions insertion/extration behavior proceed via both reactions of intercalation and conversion on the basis of four-electrons active sites. The feasibility of K-ion full cell is verified using K2Fe[Fe(CN)6] as cathode and MoS2@rGO as anode, delivering high initial capacity of 124.9 mAh·g−1 and good retention rate of 95.4% after 10 cycles at 20mA g−1. This work sheds light on the rational design of MoS2@rGO hierarchical structure with enhanced interface via chemical bonds for K-ions storage.

referenceMentions.context: Natural energy exhaustion and environmental pollution have become the major problems threatening human development, thus exploring advanced electrical energy storage (EES) technologies to integrate the renewable energy (such as solar and wind powers) into the smart electric grids is extremely urgent [1,2].

TM dichalcogenides, a type of two dimension (2D) materials, have gained considerable attention as anodes for alkali-ions storage owing to their graphene-like lamellar structure and narrow-band gap feature [38].

In particular, MoS2 possesses unique sandwich-like structure formed by weak Van der Waals force between adjacent layers and strong covalent bond linked Mo and S atoms, which provides substantial redox sites with four-electron-transfer and developed 2D channels with large interlayer distance [39], thus promoting it as an ideal host for fast K-ions insertion/extraction.
However, the huge volume change during charge/discharge process also exists for MoS2, resulting in severe capacity decay for long-term cycles [39,40].

On the basis of ex situ measurement results, the electrochemical mechanism can be described as follows: MoS2 + xK + xe ↔ KxMoS2, KxMoS2 + (4 - x)K + (4-x) e ↔ Mo + 2K2S [40].

metadata.abstractText: The abundant and low-cost potassium resources promote potassium-ion batteries (KIBs) as promising energy storage devices, thus accelerating the investigation of ideal electrode materials to accommodate the large-size Kions. Here, a nano-rose-like MoS2 confined in reduced graphene oxide (MoS2@rGO) is evaluated as anode material to boost K-ion storage. The MoS2@rGO hybrid not only features large specific surface area for excellent electron conductivity and facile K-ions diffusion, but also provides a robust three-dimension (3D) network with stable interfacial connection through strong chemical bonds (Mo-C and Mo-O-C) between MoS2 and rGO, which can alleviate the mechanical stress to guarantee the structure stability during cycling. It is also confirmed that both intercalation and conversion reaction mechanisms, based on four-electrons-transfer, play an important role in K-ions insertion/extraction. Hence, the initial capacity of 438.5 mAh·g with excellent cycling stability (capacity retention of 95.0% after 200 cycles) at 100mA g and the remarkable rate capability (196.8 mAh·g at 2 A g) among many reported anodes are achieved for MoS2@rGO. No obvious fading at 500mA g can be observed over ultra-long lifespan of 1000 cycles. Finally, the K-ion full cells are assembled with K2Fe[Fe(CN)6] cathode to demonstrate the practical application.
